title: post
values:
Its been a while since IÂ´ve written anything here.  When youÂ´re not competing and being in full action, thereÂ´s just not that much happening. Travelling around skiing and competing with the best in the world gives you a lot more to write about.  
   The good thing about not racing is that you get to meet a lot of new people. Like the crew at the Royal Norwegian Air Force.  Taking me for a trip in the F-16. ThatÂ´s something that IÂ´ve always wanted to check out. And what better time to get an invite than when youÂ´re stuck on the sofa.  A very kind thing to do and an awesome experience. Sitting in a F-16 is almost surrealistic. Like youÂ´re a part of a video game. And when youÂ´re flying over beautiful Norwegian landscape, then the scenery is almost the best part. Moving fast being able to cover a lot of ground, and still seeing everything crystal clear through the canopy.  And IÂ´ve now been travelling supersonic! Check! ThereÂ´s some risk involved. But doing extreme things with very good people never scares me that much. That means the risk is lower than it appears. I always find â€œnormalâ€ activities with unfocused and untrained people much more scary.
   Since then IÂ´ve spent my time on Florida. Relaxing on the beach, visiting friends, fishing, boating and working on my rehab training. IÂ´ve had a great time here, and the rehab progress is going well. IÂ´ll go back to Europe for some spring time later, but for now Florida has been perfect. Getting a mix of the tourist beach feeling and the local feeling staying with people that live here. Time goes by faster under the sun when you cant use the winter for skiing anyway.

Last spring we had a brainstorming session around how to connect downhill speed with fast wireless connection. This turned into a crazy idea with the potential to make a downhill gold medal into much more than a trophy hanging on the wall. This has been an exciting project. The future will be more exciting, looking at the possibilities to contribute and letting a gold medal do more than being a nice decoration on the wall.
Never checked in anywhere on Facebook before. Seems like the right thing to do at Facebook headquarters

The Olympic spirit is back in Lillehammer Norway. The Youth Olympic games happening right now. ThatÂ´s gotta be an amazing experience for a young athlete. Wish I was able to take part in something like that when i was a kid. 


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PdBQS8lp4xY

Its been almost two weeks since I went down hard in KitzbÃ¼hel. 10 days of a lot of lying in bed and sitting on the sofa. So here we go. A few reflections Iâ€™ve done.

-Shit happens!, and when it does it happens fast. One minute youÂ´re in the starting gate thinking how you can gain a few hundreds of a second through a downhill turn. Before you know it youÂ´re in the hospital wondering how many months till I can walk normally again. Thatâ€™s the way it is. You can only deal with the things you can actually do something about. And thatâ€™s usually whatÂ´s right in front of you. Be well prepared to deal with anything, but donâ€™t worry about stuff you canÂ´t influence or things you canÂ´t possibly see coming.

-Walk it off! Sounds good, but doesnâ€™t really work. I tried it, and thatâ€™s just the adrenalin walking. My knee was still busted, and by the time I got to the hospital I couldnâ€™t take a single step. But to be honest, thatâ€™s not really the reason you do it. Knowing that thereÂ´s a lot of people watching you race, and a lot of them friends and family. It is always best to show that youÂ´re ok, if you are. Downhill crashes can look real bad, and in the bigger picture a knee is not that serious. If you can, give a signal youÂ´re ok. If you get helicoptered out of there, it always takes hours before friends and family get any news about your condition. 

-Good people are awesome. IÂ´ve said this before, but it strikes me every time. ItÂ´s always nice to be around good people. But when things donâ€™t go that well, thatâ€™s when it goes from nice to crucial. IÂ´m thinking of everyone. The medical personnel that take are of you on the hill and at the hospital, your team and team mates, sponsors and your ski company, and of course friends and family! Thanks.

-Rehab training feels brutal at first. YouÂ´re used to being an athlete, and all of a sudden it feels more like being a patient. But then you start appreciating small steps and improvement, an then is actually not that bad. 

-I usually go down hard when IÂ´m skiing my best. And so have a lot of other athletes. Bad luck??? No, I donâ€™t believe it is. In downhill racing(and a lot of other sports) there will always be an element of risk. Something we all know about and that weÂ´re used to. Part of your job as an athlete is to be willing to accept this risk and push the limit so that you can go faster. To be able to win races you need to be good at overcoming your negative thoughts and be able to take enough risk. IÂ´m not necessarily a big risk seeker. So I need to convince my self that itÂ´s worth taking the risk. Taking risk when the possible outcome is winning the race, thatâ€™s a much better risk/reward ratio than when youÂ´re not in a position to win. So when the price is bigger, I have an easier time convincing myself that itÂ´s worth pushing hard. 

-So now itÂ´s back to rehab training. Do I have the motivation to go trough another rehab in just over a year? I do! With skiing as the ultimate goal of course. But thereÂ´s also a lot of other things. I want to drop the crutches as fast as I can. I wanna walk on a beach, and ride my bike somewhere cool. I wanna lift weights and do heavy workouts. To get there as fast as possible itÂ´s all the same method. Good rehab training is the answer to all these!
When a bunch of downhill racers end up at the hospital at the same time. And you do paper, scissors, rock over who gets to do surgery first. :) Gotta keep the spirit high.
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=T7tKSqVENGc

For sure not the picture and update i wanted to post after KitzbÃ¼hel. But here we are. I messed up my knee a little and about to go into surgery. Kinda sucks in the middle of the winter, but thats life. Ups and downs and just gotta deal with whatever comes.
Boom!!! Norway x3ğŸ‘Š

26th of December again and IÂ´m one year older. Boom! Time flies. Specially when youre having fun;) And the last weeks have been amazing. Speed races in Val Gardena. First with a triple win for Norway. First time ever in speed. WeÂ´re three guys on the speed team, and every body on the podium! It was also AleksÂ´ first podium, with many more to come. Then another successful day in the downhill the next day followed by a big surprise in the parallel GS in Alta Badia. A pure Norway final with Kjetil taking the win and I in 2nd. Dream day again. Add the fact that Henrik is kicking ass in slalom, and weÂ´re looking at some exciting times for the Attacking Vikings. Great to be a member of this team!! As for the last few days, theyâ€™ve been very relaxing with family. Like Christmas should be. Enjoyed a quick birthday breakfast before I dropped my dad and brother off at the airport in Innsbruck. Their off to Norway and IÂ´m gonna drive down to Italy for some more world cup racing. But in the meantime I wish everybody happy holidays and thanks a lot for all the happy birthday wishes;)
Another one!!
Menâ€™s Super G in Val Gardena: 1. Aksel 1:28.12, 2. Kjetil Jansrud +0.34, 3. Aleksander Aamodt Kilde +0.44. Downhill tomorrow.
Exciting races coming up in Val Gardena Italia. Norway 1st and 2nd in the final training today. Looking promising:) Super G Friday and downhill Saturday.  Stay tuned!

This North America trip has been great. Lake Louise was amazing and so was the downhill here in Beaver Creek. Crazy good conditions, spectacular course and Norway one and two in the race. Boom;)!! Super-G was a tough day. Difficult conditions and a totally different kind of race compared to the downhill. I also caught a bug and was throwing up the whole evening before the race. Not sure what it was, but it was a brutal one. Today I did warm up and inspection before the GS race. But still have some stomach issues and a fever, so decided to pull the plug. Ups and downs. And thatÂ´s all good when the ups are good enough to win races;) Better be 100% when the downhill tour starts in Europe again.  And that means I wont be travelling to Val d Isere either. I have been very low on energy these last days, and I think the best is to focus on the upcoming speed races and let the tech guys take care of the giant slalom. Thanks for a great start! And good luck in the GS today boys. Go Norway;);)
Wow!!!! That was big! . Norway with a double victory in Beaver Creek :)

The first speed races of the season are done and it has been a great start. I thought I was maybe good enough to win races. But thereÂ´s a big difference from that to actually doing it. Lots of fun being back racing, and very exciting to be in the start gate again. I would be lying if I said I wasnâ€™t nervous, but thatâ€™s part of the experience. It wouldnâ€™t be the same without the adrenaline and the slightly uncomfortable moments. But thanks to being a part of a great team, both with the ski federation and with Head, I was ready to go fast! Now that the winter has really started there will be tons of exciting races coming up. Almost every weekend. First one is Beaver Creek this Friday through Sunday, and then weÂ´re off to Europe again. I for sure wont win every race, but the most important thing is being fast enough so you can win. If youÂ´ve got the speed, then the racing is exciting and good things happen!
Super G (Lake Louise):
What's your limit??
Back on skis! More details to follow.

Aksel won the 1st downhill of the season in Lake Loiuse (CAN) - only 0.01 seconds ahead of Peter Fill and Travis Ganong (+0.36). Today at 19:00 (CET) is on the same track scheduled Super G. Aksel with #19!

Race time;)

ItÂ´s time to race again. World Cup opening in SÃ¶lden Autria is on this weekend. A strange feeling. It has been more than 18 months since I last raced a world cup race. I did the two races at the World Championships in Beaver Creek last year, so I hope I havenâ€™t totally forgotten everything. I am happy it swinter time again. I might not be perfectly prepared for this race here in SÃ¶lden. Its Giant Slalom. And focusing on coming back in the speed disciplines I havenâ€™t been abel to work that much on my GS. But some runs IÂ´m pretty fast and I its for sure worth a try. ItÂ´s about time to get that race feeling. Being on the sidelines for so long I feel I need a few starts before I perfectly back in rhythm. So better start here in SÃ¶lden and then be 100% prepared for the downhill in Lake Louise. Skiing is fun and racing is exciting, so here we go!!

Short summer update

Its August. For a skier that means the winter is almost here. From the end of August till April is all about snow, winter and skiing. Getting as much as possible of  it in the fall, and then make the most out of it when the winter arrives in Europe/North America. So you better enjoy the summer days that you do get. And I have. ItÂ´s been a busy summer. Busy training with the guys on the team, travelling around Europe and also spending a few perfect lazy summer days at the family cabin. IÂ´ve also spent a lot of time working on some other projects that have nothing to do with skiing. Trying to learn some other skills and checking out what other exciting stuff this world has to offer. The time that I was injured gave me the opportunity to get to know some new people, and I really enjoy spending time with them and talking about everything else but sports. Sports and skiing is for sure still number one. And most important right now is that IÂ´m healthy and looking forward to the winter. Right now IÂ´m at a ski camp at Passe Stelvio Italiy. The achilles feels so good inside the ski boot that I donâ€™t even think about it any more.  And physically IÂ´m close to the same level that I was before the injury. Thanks to my team mates. â€œThe Attacking Vikingsâ€. Those guys impress me everyday. Great attitude and theyÂ´re starting to look super strong. Cant wait to get the whole team together again on snow in Chile in a few weeks. I think weÂ´re looking at another exciting winter for team Norway!
A fun little commercial we did for DNB two weeks ago. In Norwegian, but I think the concept is pretty cool even if you can't understand the dialog.

My team wrapped up the season with a great world cup final, while I wrapped up the season with a fun powder trip to Alaska. And that Alaska trip marked the end of my winter 14/15 solo mission. Being injured you spend a lot of time by yourself. Doing your rehab training and travelling back and forward between different groups and different resorts to get some ski training.  Cause the show must go on. And winter time means race time. Thatâ€™s what has priority, and when you cant be a part of that, you find your own way. Not completely by yourself, but its more or less up to yourself to make the best out of the situation. But not anymore. Feels great to be 100% back with the team again. Being healthy enough to take part in the normal everyday activity and not slowing anyone down. We have a couple of good camps and weÂ´ve started the summer dryland training. Was hoping for some good skiing in Austria this week, but weather not cooperating at the moment. But IÂ´ll keep my eyes open for some more skiing. IÂ´ve got some work to do to catch up what I lost this winter! The physical condition is good. I was able to get a lot of good physical training even with the cast on my foot. In fact I was back at my normal maxium squat(leg strength) level just weeks after loosing the cast. Still a bit behind on the running and biking, but its getting there. So hereÂ´s to a spring with good training and great sessions back with the boys!

This is what my face looked like after 28.5 kilometers at the #wingsforlife #worldrun  Because of my achilles injury im not ready for the challenge. But I'll be driving the car in the background trying to catch your ass. Check out #wingsforlife and sign up!!
The last few weeks has been an adventure. In remote places exploring mountains I had never skied before. Thanks Field Productions for an exciting trip.

The rest of the season

The world championships in Beaver Creek was a great experience. The whole process of trying to get ready in time was one big challenge. I like challenges. And in the end it worked out, but with a margin of only a day or two. It was probably pushing it a little bit to ski in the world champs. But I felt it was under control. Ever since I left Beaver Creek IÂ´ve been thinking a lot about what to do with the rest of the season.  How I feel on skis being my number one priority. How the injury looks being the number one priority for the medical team. The other aspect is what risks IÂ´m taking with my starting positions for next year. As we all know start numbers make a big difference in ski racing. I feel pretty good on the skis, but I also feel that I missed those three months of skiing. To be back 100% I will need a lot more skiing, but if everything runs perfect I think it would be possible to do some good races. Achilles also looks good. But as the guys at the Olympic center in Oslo said, â€œyou still have three months of rehab training left, dont forget that!â€. And then we have the aspect with the staring position. To describe it simple it works something like this; If you are injured you get injury status. An injury is something that FIS says it takes 8 months to recover from. So if youÂ´re back quicker, then you get no injury status. This means that if I start skiing World Cup now IÂ´m not injured and never was. And that means I have the last few races of the season to try and collect the same ranking points that the other guys have used the whole winter to collect. If I donâ€™t collect them I will start next season with a bad start number. I have done the math, and it would be possible to make it happen. But that is if everything runs perfect. Including weather and other factors that I cant control, because I couldnâ€™t afford any races being cancelled. So between the math and good advice from people I trust I have landed on the decision that I will use the rest of this winter to get back to good old shape. In other words no more races. Both skiing and physical rehab needs a lot more work. And this way I have the time to get it done right. Come to the beginning of next season fully prepared and be ready to attack 100% again. Thanks for the support during world champs. That meant a lot!! And it was almost unreal to be back way earlier then I expected. But back at Olympic center it was clearly back to reality. 3 more months of rehab trainingâ€¦

Aksel

Another close race here in Beaver Creek. Another 6th place and again just 14 hundreds from the medals.  That's it for me here at the world championship. Its been a great experience. Both racing here,  and also the journey I took to get her.  A lot work with a lot of great people. Thanks!!! We didn't know if it would be possible to get back on skis this soon. But with nothing to lose we made every day count. I wish I got a medal. That would have made this perfect! But I'm still very happy I got to race here. Thanks to the organization and the volunteers here in Beaver Creek for all the smiles and the good atmosphere.  I'll see you again next year;)
Best 6th place ever, considering I was told 3 months ago I should spend this winter on the sidelines... ;)

Colorado Training
Colorado is the place to be in November. With Europe struggling with warm temperatures it seems that Colorado is your safest bet to get good training. The ski resorts here being at about 3500 meter altitude is close to a guarantee that youÂ´ll get low temperatures. Because of this it is also crowded. Almost every downhill team on the World Cup seems to be here. Every day of training is a mini World Cup race. Both on the mens and the womens side.  Americans, Germans, Austrians, Swiss and Norwegians training on the same mountain. Looking at each other trying to figure out who looks strong for the winter. Thanks to a good cooperation with the American team weÂ´ve gotten some really good days. Now weÂ´ve got this week, and then itÂ´s off to Lake Louise for the first downhill world cup. I think weÂ´re as prepared as we could hope for, so lets see what happens;)

SÃ¶lden was a tough race. I knew that coming in, but you still hoped to do great. But thatâ€™s all history now and its time to fly to America and get the downhill worldcup going! Racing sure is way different from training. Everything about it. Easy to forget that. ItÂ´s exciting. And the best giant slalom guys are really good. Impressive level of skiing by the top guys in SÃ¶lden. And congrats Ted for being back on top in GS.

South America

September might the one month with the most skiing for the Norwegian team. We spend the whole month in South America preparing for the upcoming season. Sure thereÂ´s a lot of skiing in the winter. But when youÂ´re racing its just a few runs, and in training you can do 10++.  So September is probably the most important month of the year when it comes to actually getting better. And I think we did get better in this year. Like always in the mountains thereÂ´s a lot of weather and changing conditions. But staying for a month youÂ´re pretty much guarantied to get some good, and then it doesnâ€™t matter if its not great for a week or two. First two weeks of speed training in Portillo, and then we met up with the tech boys for two and a half week in Valle Nevado. ItÂ´s fun to get together with the tech boys(yes, theyÂ´re young and thatÂ´s why I say boys..) and get a refreshing perspective. ItÂ´s easy to do the same over and over again, but skiing with this 10 year younger crew it kinda takes me 10 years back as well. Now weÂ´re back in Europe and weÂ´ll soon start skiing on the glaciers in Austria. The season feels close, and its all about making the most out of the last weeks of quality training. IÂ´m excited about the winter and that its soon time to race again.
My date for the weekend.  Please be nice to me...

A fun challenge coming up this weekend when Marcel Hirscher, Felix Neureuther and I will try out the world of a professional race car driver. Audi TT cup at Red Bull Ring. A bunch of real pilots and three amateurs. And judging by this video Marcel looks pretty confident after some practice! Goal number one here is to have plenty of fun;)

Back to "just skiing";)

As a kid I would ski a lot in the winter. That kinda changes once you reach world cup level. There are so many races, that there is very little room for training days. And during a race day there is more talking about skiing then there is actual skiing. In the morning you inspect the course for about an hour. Then you talk to the coaches. Watch some of the other racers and get feedback from your coaches again after theyâ€™ve seen a few guys. Then you finally get to ski yourself, but only one or two runs during the day. And then you spend time talking to the media about those few minutes of skiing. Before you look at your run again in the evening and talk to the coaches about how to get better. Its all exciting and competition is fun. But there is not a lot of actual skiing during a race season. Most of the skiing you want to get done needs to happen during summer and fall. But now that IÂ´m not doing races I have way more time to just ski. IÂ´ve been skiing almost every day since I was able to put a ski boot on around mid January. ItÂ´s back to how thing used to be when I was a junior, and I like it a lot. Training with the junior team, the Europa cup team and the slalom guys. Like in the picture when Kjetil Lars and I were working our way up. Getting lots of skiing done and working on the technique more than looking at the times and thinking about speed.  Getting a reminder of how fun the pure skiing is, without lots of people around and getting attention from media etc. ItÂ´s fun and I think itâ€™s a great way to start preparing for next winter. Cause then its back to â€œnormalâ€. Ski in the summer/fall and spend the winter talking about skiing ;)
Spending the day testing next years production skis with Head. Good stuff ;)
My obsession lies between a start house and a finish line. Where is yours? #LiveYours #TeamOakley oak.ly/oneobsession

Made it safely down the downhill course;) So I guess world champs it is. Not the preparation I was hoping for.  But I've been lucky to come into many championships in top form.  This time its different. But if everyone that didn't have a perfect preparation decided to drop the races. Then there wouldn't be much of a championship. So this time it's my turn to try and attack from the back;)

The world championship plan

So the big question is if I will be able to race the championships here in Beaver Creek.  And the honest answer is that I don't know. But I think I'm close enough that it's worth giving it a try. So I'll ski the official downhill training tomorrow and then just take it from there day by day. Will I be good enough to win a medal?? I have no idea. And probably not. I didn't ski for three whole months while these other guys were racing around the world.

But I'm not taking anyone else's spot in the championships. I have my own spot cause I'm the defending champion. So I guess this time it's more for the love of the game. I miss the action. And the fact is that if you're at the start you still have a chance of success. The only way of having no chance is by not taking part.

And I like the challenge. In October most people told me that I was out for the whole winter. I just want to see what's possible. And here we are. Beginning of February and I do believe it's possible for me to ski the Birds of Prey downhill here in Beaver Creek. And then we'll just see day by day what happens. I'm ready to give it a try and then we'll just take it from there.

Aksel

Skiing Aspen CO

Skiing in Aspen this week . And the skiing is beautiful!! ItÂ´s world champion conditions and hero snow. That means youÂ´ll feel like a world champion skiing. And the snow lets you rip crazy sharp turns. Turning like a hero. Add blue skies and youÂ´re probably looking at some of the best skiing on the planet right now. A real confidence builder for an injured athlete trying to make his way back.  You can probably tell IÂ´m pretty excited. Thatâ€™s what happens when you walk around on crutches looking at all youÂ´re friends skiing all winter. You miss it. And then you start nice and slowly. Hoping things work out. And it kinda does, but not 100% like you hoped for. But then these sweet conditions come along and give you that extra little help you needed. Skiing is a lot of fun on days like these. This week in Aspen is turning out to be real good. Or real awesome as I should say here in America.
Norwegian 16 year old Martin Ã˜degaard just got signed by Real Madrid.  Congrats!!

Skiing with boys.

Mid last week I tried skiing for the first time. Thatâ€™s a week ago now and the progress has been great. I was very optimistic before the first day. I figured the foot would feel as good and safe inside a ski boot, as it did inside the cast. This was of course way too optimistic, so I was a bit disappointed. But now its slowly getting there. Still problems in rough conditions, but that too keeps getting better. This week I can almost follow a normal training, so IÂ´ve joined up with parts of the team in Hinterreit Austria. Feels great to be back with the boys. And even better, IÂ´ve decided to join them for the training camp in Colorado. IÂ´ll fly over on Sunday and then I get almost a week of skiing in Aspen before I have to decide of IÂ´m ready to do races at the world champs or not. Its still far away, but the progress is promising. And even if I donâ€™t make the championship, that will probably be the best training anywhere in the world. So itâ€™s a win win long and short term. On my way to the airport IÂ´ll stop by Kitzbuhel to check out the downhill on Saturday. With Jansruds speed right now that might be a good day for Norway!
Ripping around Innsbruck today. Good to be back on the mountain!

Marry Christmas everyone.  
A little help from #WeVideo to capture that holiday spirit :)

The Silicon Valley Experience

 Sometimes shit happens. And when youÂ´re an athlete and that â€œshitâ€ is an injury, then your life is changed until youÂ´re a 100% recovered. ItÂ´s for sure not the end of the world, but youÂ´re life just looks a lot different the next weeks or months. So what to do? I found no positive side to this situation within my world, the world of sports. So I started looking for other alternatives that I find interesting and inspiring.  
     Trough my career IÂ´ve gotten to know a lot of great people in different fields and environments. And trough this IÂ´ve learned that entrepreneurs, people that start their own businesses and companies, think a lot like athletes do. They set high goals that are hard to reach, but theyÂ´re willing to take the risk and reach for their goals. And they often do so with energy and passion that I recognize from sports. So I quickly realized that this would be the perfect opportunity for me to keep my mind occupied while IÂ´m doing (boring) rehab training.  Spending time with experienced (and hopefully smart!) entrepreneurs. Have fun, get inspired and maybe learn something at the same time. And where do you find an environment thatÂ´s full of experienced entrepreneurs?? The Bay Area. San Francisco and Silicon Valley is home to some of the biggest companies and most innovative companies in the world. Companies whoÂ´s product we use every day. Like Facebook and Google. But more important, itÂ´s full of innovative companies driven by people with a passion and a vision to create what could be the as important as Google 10 years from now. 
     Thanks to a little help for some good friends in Oslo, some new friends I made a long the way, and a very open and welcoming culture here in Silicon Valley, this trip was everything I hoped it would be. Very inspiring, lots of fun, and filled with lessons to learn.  I have spent every day with people I had never met before, but that were still willing to share both their time and their experiences.  At companies like Google, or at some cafÃ© with someone willing to risk everything on an idea thatâ€™s just on a piece of paper. Both with same enthusiasm and conviction that theyÂ´re working on something big. 
     I hope that IÂ´ve learned something.  I like this â€œindustry of big ideasâ€ a lot. And thatâ€™s probably the most important lesson. That this is something that I have fun with. Cause when youÂ´re having fun youÂ´re working harder and better. ThatÂ´s something that I believe will never change.  Hard work pays off! 
     So if youÂ´re walking around somewhere on this planet, and you have a great idea in your mind. Or a feeling in your stomach that you want to create something. Explore that idea and see whatÂ´s possible. Donâ€™t keep it a secret, cause trough sharing and conversations youÂ´ll probably attract others with a similar mindset. And that is the first lesson I learned here. ThereÂ´s thousands of great ideas and the competition is big. What can separate you is having a great team of people and being able to execute on your idea. 
     I had good friends helping me out to get started. But I have met just as many inspiring people just staying in the area. The Nordic countries have put together a shared working space called the Nordic Innovation House. A great place were IÂ´ve spent a lot of time. So if youÂ´re from the Nordic region youÂ´ll have a great start right there.  And IÂ´m sure other countries have similar projects. So if you have that entrepreneur spirit and you wanna give it a chance. Go explore! Only then will you know whatÂ´s possible.  ThatÂ´s my conclusion. But be aware, right now I might be under the influence of some of the best entrepreneurs in the world ;)
JOY and smiles all around;)  Go to the HEAD Facebook page to see how you can win a pair of the brand new JOY skis.  #smilesofjoy

Rehab update

Thanks to a lot of good support and some hard work IÂ´m happy to say that the rehab training is going very well. This week Iâ€™m gonna loose this plastic cast that Iâ€™ve been walking around with lately. That means the achilles tendon itself is slowly growing back to be one piece. But its still not the same strength. But thatâ€™s an even bigger problem with the muscles in my leg and around the ankle. Even though Iâ€™ve been working them every day, that is still nothing compered to how you use your muscles when youÂ´re just moving around without a cast on. So even though the cast thing is coming off, I suspect I still have to walk with the crutches for a few days. And thatâ€™s kind of a good thing. Cause once you get a good technique on those things theyÂ´re real fast.   But even though I have a way to go IÂ´m pretty optimistic. I do have a feeling IÂ´m a little ahead of schedule. So lets wait and see what happened in the next few months. The achillies tendon is about double of what it used to be in thickness, so iÂ´m gonna have to drop by the Head factory to get a new pair of boots fitted. Not sure when IÂ´ll be able to take those boots skiing. But like I said, t looks good and IÂ´m kinda optimistic.

A fun little trip we did to the mountains around Wengen and Kitzbuhel last winter. We didn't get the powder we were after, but we got some nice climbing in spectacular scenery.

Shit happens. And that's exactly what's happened this time. I was out for a little run with the rest of the team in SÃ¶lden Austria.  We ended the session playing around with a ball. Just holding it up in the air between us. Suddenly I felt something snap in my leg and I knew right away that something was wrong.  Achilles. 

We went straight to the hospital in Innsbruck where I got fast and great service. They concluded the achilles was torn and after 5 minutes of talking I went straight to surgery. 

A real injury and extremely bad timing just as the season is about to start. But now that it's happened there's not much I can do. Now it's all about looking ahead. Nobody can say 100% sure how long the recovery will take, but I'm ready for the weeks to that are coming.  

I'll stay in Austria for a while before I go back to Norway and discuss further rehab with the crew at the Olympic Center in Oslo. 

Like I said. Shit happens!

IÂ´ve skied my whole life. Skiing being an outside sport, it is also a sport that is effected by weather. Add being in the mountains and youÂ´re effected by a lot of weather.  During my time as a ski racer I have been to many camps where the weather and conditions have not been on our side. ItÂ´s almost normal that you lose a few days and/or get some days with real bad conditions. Bad conditions as a ski racers usually means that the snow is bad. It can be very soft. Or the snow is braking up into balls(we call it death cookies). Or its just hard enough for cruising, but once you push hard it breaks away under your ski. Or it is just very little snow. Very little snow means rocks. Since rocks destroy your skis, you canÂ´t use your race skis. And training if you canÂ´t use your best equipment is not the same. Snow in general is very sensitive to weather conditions. But youÂ´re also depending on the crew that work the hill. That they know what theyÂ´re doing when theyÂ´re running the groomers. Basically there is a lot of things that can easily mess up your training. Imagine being a football player. One day the grass is just dirt and hard as asphalt , one day itÂ´s half a meter tall and the next day its so wet that you run with water over your ankles. You can still practice, but its not very game/match/race like, you cant be your best and after a while that gets old. And thatâ€™s just the snow. Add wind(sometimes so strong the lifts wont run), rain, snow and fog. All normal in the mountains. There are just a lot of things that would make a lot of other sports easier when it comes to getting good training. If I go somewhere I like to stay for a long time. This way I feel you minimize the luck when it comes to weather. Staying long enough in one place youÂ´re gonna get good stuff sooner or later. ThatÂ´s why we spend the whole month of September(and then some) in Argentina. Like I said, going somewhere for a week you need some luck, and you could easily lose half of your days or more. But going somewhere for a month and having shit conditions almost every day!!! Thatâ€™s a first for me. And hopefully a lastâ€¦  Coaches, ski technicians and racers are all working hard and hoping every day for good conditions.  When you get disappointed by what the weather has done to the conditions almost every day you come up on the mountainâ€¦ Well, it gets frustrating in the end. This September in Ushuaia most be the worst ski camp IÂ´ve ever been to. We have just had real bad luck, for a month straightâ€¦ Hopefully that will change for October and November, so we can get some quality training and be ready for another fun winter season!! And I think theyÂ´re right. If youÂ´re frustrated about something it helps to get it outâ€¦ Thanks!

Being a part of the best team is great when youÂ´re having success and everybody Â´s happy. But its even better when things donâ€™t go your way. Thatâ€™s when you really figure out what kind of people and companies you work with. I decided to stay in SÃ¶lden for the world cup races. Not to watch the races, but because I wanted to be with my team. These guys are great at what they do (athletes, coaches, physios, ski techniciansâ€¦) but theyÂ¨re also great people and some of my best friends. 
    
IÂ´m also a proud member of the HEAD ski team. Yesterday we did the annual world cup opening press conference with the HEAD team here in SÃ¶lden. Everyone else ready to kick ass trough the winter, and me jumping around on one footâ€¦ A lot of people said it must be really depressing to be here?? No, its actually exactly the opposite. I felt so much better after those hours spent with the HEAD crew. Being injured I feel bad because I cant deliver results and excitement on the race hill like I normally do.  I will be back sooner or later to do that again, but in the mean time IÂ´m on the side lines watching.  Skiing is a risky sport and weÂ´re all used to injuries, but it still feels great when you get the kind of support that I felt yesterday. So thanks everyone! And like I said. ItÂ´s good to be a part of a great team when things are good. But when things donâ€™t go youÂ´re wayâ€¦ ThatÂ´s when being a part of right team gets really important.

Being a part of the new generation.

During the winter I travel around and race world cup. It used to be a big team, then I had some years almost alone, and the last few years I have had the company of Kjetil and sometimes some other guys. Athletes have different events they focus on, and you need to spend some time on the FIS and the Europa Cup tour before youÂ´re ready for a full World Cup season. But in the summer we all do the same thing. And that is to work out, hard!! 
Given my experience and age(yes, iÂ´m over  30 nowâ€¦) IÂ´m kind of a team captain. Nothing official, but I try to help out and share some of my experience. Like Kjetil Andre Aamodt thought me a lot of stuff when I first joined the team. Not a big deal, just something thatÂ´s natural in any team. But IÂ´m liking it more and more. I think its inspiring. And thatÂ´s for one reason alone. These guys are awesome! A new generation of seriously Attacking Vikings. We are all different and sure we donâ€™t agree on everything. But a great attitude and a respect for hard work is something shared by this whole group. After 6 weeks together pushing hard every day IÂ´m impressed. And IÂ´m sure it will bring results. Most of you already know a guy like Henrik, but there are more coming.  Watch out. The attitude and the work moral makes me proud to say that this is my team and they are my team mates.  Thatâ€™s a real clischÃ©, I know. But thatÂ´s what 6 weeks of hard work will do to you. On this last day when itÂ´s time for a few weeks of holiday we all feel a little emotional.
Keep training boys, but also get some well earned rest!!

May has been quit busy. It seems that every year May just flies by. After Japan it was back to Norway for 17th of May celebration. Always fun. Seeing lots of friends and family out in Oslo. And also the annual 16th of May party hosted by Stordalen. I love parties where you dress up. The theme this year was Norway. Its 200 years since the Norwegian constitution was written back in 1814, and that of course is a great reason to celebrate. Not only partying in Oslo of course. I got some great bike rides with friends and god lifting sessions at the Olympic gym. Then it was back to Innsbruck. The great thing about Innsbruck is that youÂ´re in the middle of the ski world. Not only during winter, but almost more so in summer. Within one hour driving you have 5 world class glacier summer ski resorts.  WeÂ´ve been training in Kaunertal. Living close by you can pick and choose the days when the conditions and the weather forecast looks the best. We got some great days. Being on the mountain around 5am to take advantage for the cold nights. Good training and great preparation with HEAD getting the skis ready for another winter. No itÂ´s off to Trentino and Lake Garda for a week of training with the team. Both A and B team will be there, so itâ€™s a big group. ItÂ´s gonna be hard work being chased by 20year olds all week. Like I said, May is busy. But busy with exciting stuff;)

Thanks for the #icebucketchallenge Gregor Schlierenzauer. As I was already dressed up like this when I received your challenge, I decided to stay in #Matrix character. I wanna challenge my current team mate Aleksander Kilde, my legendary team mate Kjetil AndrÃ© Aamodt, and of course Keanu Reeves to see if he can put on the real moves!

The summer 2014

A skier doesnâ€™t get a lot of summer. You extend the winter as far as you can into the spring. Then you start looking for snow again as soon as August comes around. That basically means two months of summer. June and July. Good thing these months were both amazing in Scandinavia this year. In June I spent most of my time in Oslo training with the team. I a few short trips to Innsbruck and some days at my summer house in Sweden. But most of the time was spent with the team working out. Good times and good workouts. A win win situation thanks to great team mates!
    We got three weeks of vacation from the team. The first week I spent with friends from New York biking trough the French Alps. We started in Annecy and ended up on the Riviera. ThatÂ´s something I would recommend to everyone. If you like biking, beautiful nature and a bit of a challenge you should try that some day. Two relaxing days on the Riviera felt real good after climbing some of the most famous mountain passes in the Alps. IÂ´m for sure doing that again!
   Then I spent two weeks at my house in Sweden in the craziest summer weather I have ever experienced in Scandinavia. High 20Â´s to mid 30Â´s every day. Hot, but so nice when youÂ´re by the sea and you can just dive in whenever you need to cool off. Perfect for recharging the batteries. 
   Cause the last week of July it all starts again. Physical testing at the Olympic center in Oslo and back training with the team. And now that itÂ´s August itÂ´s back on snow. A short week of skiing at Passo Stelvio in Italia and later in August weÂ´ll travel to South America for a 5 week camp in Chile and Argentina. 
   The summer was great, but also a bit short. Cant believe itÂ´s all starting again. It feels kinda early. But IÂ´m hoping to catch a few more days in shorts and t-shirt  before its all winter again for the next 10 monthsâ€¦

Japan!

One thing is clear. We race on the FIS WORLD CUP. That means we should try to race all around the world. And for sure in Japan. ItÂ´s been too long and the Japanese are really excited about skiing. The ski community is not as big as it was in the early 90Â´s, but the interest is still there. And walking trough the streets of Tokyo you can run into ski shops and pro race shops. An unusal thing. It almost feels like walking by a ski rental in the middle of Manhatten.  But we the ski areas just one hour away with the bullet train, Tokyo is different and the potential for big interest is really there. I have just had some great days in Japan. Getting to know our clothing supplier Phenix a lot better and really learning more about the whole process that goes into making the clothing. But also visiting a lot of ski shops and ski communities. ItÂ´s been a great experience and I hope we can bring world cup skiing back to Japan soon.

That was two weeks of vacation and now its back on the mountain. Practice makes perfect. Or at least better. 5 am start means the snow is still nice and hard from the cold night. At around 10 its starting to get real soft and our day on the mountain is over. Back to bed for some well earned extra sleep. Today was close to perfect here in RÃ¸ldal and Im hoping we get more days like that. Getting up at 4 is a lot easier if its clear sky, compared to getting up when you hear the rain hitting your bedroom window. I said it was 2 weeks of vacation. Before this camp. In a ay thats true even though it was no real vacation. I spent most  of my time between the last ski camp and this one at the gym. Lifting weights. But thats the whole idea of vacation. Doing something different. And after 5-6 months with intense skiing and very little time for lifting, it is actually fun to get back to the gym and do something different. It sure doesnt always feel that way. So better take advantage and get a lot of training done now that IÂ´m feeling excited about it. But this week is all about skiing. Getting a lot of good turns done!

After a long winter with lots of skiing, then there is more skiingâ€¦ We have started the training for next season. Just spent a week in Kvitfjell with great conditions. If youÂ´re lucky in and get good weather in the spring, you get great conditions in the morning before that sun heats everything up too much.  Last week was some of the best conditions I have seen all winter. Now its off to Ã…re Sweden for a HEAD camp. HEAD athletes gathered to test next years equipment. Always fun to see of we can find something thatâ€™s faster than what we have. We usually do! We will also be recording some material for next year. A new film. Last yearÂ´s â€œpokerâ€ film was a big hit so we need something good again this year.

Its been a while since I wrote anything on this blog. The last part of the season was draining. In the race season you donâ€™t ski that much during the winter. You do some warm up and freeskiing, but the actual skiing in races is always less then 5 minutes. And when youÂ´ve finished your 5 min of skiing you get to talk about it with the media for about 1 hour and 5 minutes. That doesnâ€™t mean that the media is bad. But IÂ´m a skier. And 5 min of skiing followed by 1 hour and 5 min talking about skiing is gets tiring after a long winter. So I havenâ€™t
really had the energy to wright about skiing either. But now IÂ´ve spent some time alone, or at least away from most people. So now IÂ´m back. First I skied a little in the Swiss alps, then I went to Austria to climb the Grossglockner. A fun experience. A lot of people go to the summit of Grossglockner. I think that is impressive, cause the last part is challenging. A narrow spine to climb and walk with something that looks like 1000 meters vertical on both sides. Sure get your heart pumping a little faster.  And with this new energy that I got from spending some time â€œaloneâ€ in the mountains IÂ´m heading to Norway for the national championships. Hope you all have a great last part of the winter and try to get more then 5 minutes of skiing a day!

The speed races in Val Gardena are done. Good stuff for team Norway! A win for me yesterday and a 2nd for Kjetil today. In my interviews i was always asked how surprising it is to see Kjetil back after his ACL injury. The question surprises me every time. The mentality outside our team must be very different. As a team we work towards being fast and fast enough to win races. Kjetil has been that fast for some time now. Its our job as a team to keep that winning mentality.  Instead on focusing on the past, we look forward.  Instead of saying "that's good enough, you had a knee injury". We look for more speed and work on getting better. Never let the level drop. We want to be fast. And even when old and famous skiers who are now "media experts" claimed that Kjetil didnt have a chance this season. We choose not to listen. Cause we know better. So there you go. Congrats Team Norway!

Going home.

Olympics are over for me. Like many other athletes here in Sochi I've been struggling with some sort of allergi. I've been given medicines, trying hard to keep everything around me clean and the usual stuff that people do when they get allergic.  It's helped, but not enough and it only seems to be getting worse. I could still win medals in my to favorite events, but now that those chances are gone it's time to face reality and get out of here. Feels sad as I still have the Giant Slalom to race and i also wanted to stay for a few days and watch other sports. But new goals ahead and it's time to realize the Olympic dream is over and focus what's ahead. I'm lucky that ski racing has a great worldcup so I don't have to wait very long before I can race again. Thanks for the support everyone. And keep supporting the Attacking Vikings in the last two events.

Lars 

ItÂ´s the summer of 2000. IÂ´m on the Norwegian Junior Ski Team and we are at Folgefonna glacier in Norway training. There is a new kid around. Lars Myhre. HeÂ´s not apart of the team, but he has skied so well with his school that he is invited to join us for training. Immediately he kicks our ass with an all-in full gas intensity that I had never seen. And thatÂ´s it. He skis so well that he makes the team right there and then. As the only room left in the house that we are renting is in my tiny double bed(IÂ´m taking euro tiny, way smaller than American queen size), Lars still stays with his school for that camp. And this is something Lars and I have disagreed on ever since. Did he not move in because I said NO this bed is too small for the two of us??, or didnâ€™t he want to move in because the bed was too small. Hahaha! What was it Lars?? 
And since that summer day in 2000 Lars has been my team mate and one of my best friends. Later that season Kjetil Jansrud also made the Junior team. And it has been the three of us that made it every step from that team and to world championships and Olympics. Good races, bad races, but most off all just a lot of fun!
After a back injury last season Lars has been struggling. ItÂ´s sad that he is stopping his career. But the good news for all of you people out there is that he is a great guy and an excellent commentator on TV. Just hired by TV2 to cover the Olympics and some of the biggest races. So you all will see a lot more of him! Enjoy! IÂ´m looking forward to seeing Lars at the races in Beaver Creek.

South America, itÂ´s a wrap.

Ended our South American skiing adventure in the pouring rain. But luckily that was one of very few days we didnâ€™t have good training on this trip. That doesnâ€™t mean we had perfect conditions every day, but we had good training almost every day. Some days sunny, some in flat light. Some days on hard snow, and some one soft. Just like the winter will probably be. When we land in Europa in a few days that marks the end of a 5 weeks long trip. ThatÂ´s a long time. But when you have good training and a great team, then 5 weeks are actually not that long. So hereÂ´s to you guys. Team mates, coaches and ski techs. For making 5 weeks of hard training fly by like it was nothing!

I have known Julia for many years. The last 4 years we have shared a great relationship together. We have had the best time. But time is also a limited resource. . There is a long distance between our homes where we both live busy life. Spending enough time together has been a tough challenge and itÂ´s difficult to see how that would change for the future.  So after spending another great summer together we have decided that we want to try going our separate ways. I usually donâ€™t share a lot from my private life, but there you go. Instead of people speculating I thought is was better to share the simple truth from a complicated situation. Ending a relationship is never fun, but I think we did this the smartest way possible. Thanks Julia, for figuring this out with me.

This spring I have been driving an Audi SQ5 around Europe. And this little SUV was a great surprise. It handles great in the city, on the highway and on narrow mountain  roads. A perfect compromise. Looks great with the S-LINE styling and the 21Â¨ wheels. The 313hp 650nm diesel delivers great performance with excellent fuel economy. And the exhaust gives V8 like sound. I have had many cars, but this SQ5 was great everywhere. And a little detail that I liked a lot was the advanced cup-holder. Just push a button an it will keep your drink cold, or push again and turn on the heater to keep your coffee warm. 

So i have never done a car review before. But the SQ5 surprised me a lot, so I wanted to let you know.

ItÂ´s that time again... World Cup. Racing.

After a great camp in Portillo we travelled on on Ushuaia. Ushuaia is in Patagonia in the far south of Argentina. Ushuaia is actually southernmost city in the world. In other words pretty far away from Norway. Especially for our physio Trond. He is from the north of Norway and started his travels in the northernmost city in the world, Hammerfest. So when you travel this far it better be worth it. And so far its looking pretty good. We have only skied two days and have more than two weeks left, but I think this could be good. They have more snow than last year. The nature down here in Patagonia is great. It looks a lot like the north of Norway, and that is a good thing. Kinda wish I haf some touring stuff and skins with me too, thereÂ´s plenty of cool peaks around. But hopefully the training will be so good that I donâ€™t have the time or the energy for that.

Winter time!!

This week is the final week of summer training. IÂ´ve skied a few weeks, but for the last 4 months itÂ´s been 99% summer training and only a little skiing. That is all about to change. South America is the place to be for the next 5 weeks. 

Summer has been great in every way. IÂ´ve been lucky to be injury free. Except for two weeks of the flue in June, IÂ´ve been fit and able to work out hard every day. I tested well at the Olympic center in Oslo and I feel very healthy. Maybe a little too healthy. ItÂ´s been a very active summer. Lots of normal training, but also lots of other activities.  One or two workout session a day plus surfing, sailing, biking and playing means a lots of calories burned. I eat healtier in the summer than the winter. Being able to make your own food or choosing what restaurant to eat at gives me the option to eat better. Travelling the world during the winter this can be tougher. But maybe not better for a downhill skier?? During the testing at the Olympic center I discovered I had lost 4 kilos. As gravity is my motor, I need all the kilos and horsepower I can get trying to go faster. 

But do not fear. I know I will get back to 100 kilos in no time.  The last 10 days I have tried eating more and adding some more calories to my diet. By doing so IÂ´ve gained about 2 kilos again. 2 kilos of pure speed. 

And now its off to South America and get that speed and those kilos on the snow. Excited!!! ItÂ´s about time to get back to businessâ€¦

We had 10 great days in Lyngen. Or more precise, 5 amazing days and 5 ok days. Together that is 10 great days. For 5 days everything was 100%. Blue sky, no wind good snow and snow stabile enough to ski steep mountains. The last few days it got too warm and the snow melted. Thatâ€™s bad cause you donâ€™t get that powder feeling, but also bad from a safety aspect. The top layer melts in the sun and warm winds, making the snow unstable and an avalanche much more likely. ItÂ´s the combination of ocean, fjords and mountains that makes the nature in northern Norway so special. It feels like there is not a single meter of boring terrain. And you donâ€™t have to hike for to get to the fun, steep skiing. Stop your car on the side of the road, and it begins right there. Also fun seeing  how the locals  are proud of their nature and very welcoming when you come to visit their backyard.  I had a lot of fun skiing and hiking in Lyngen this year, and I hope the film crew got some good footage so it will look just as fun on film.

Overwhelming 

These last 24 hours have been unreal. Not so much the part where I won s ski race. More all thatÂ´s followed after. It started when I crossed the finish line and felt like I had 40.000 spectators cheering for me. Even though weÂ´re in Austria and IÂ´m competing against their home racers.  But great supporters always cheer for everyone, and the Austrians sure did yesterday. Thank you! Then you have the interviews and parties that follow.  And again it is the kind words that make it seem unreal. Specially when they come from heroes like Kjetil Andre Aamodt or Didier Cuche, but also the greetings and compliments I have received from everyone from Norway. The king, the prime minister and lots of other athletes from different sports have all sent praises and congratulations. Thanks a lot, and sorry for not being able to get back to you all. Its almost too much. Thank you!

KitzbÃ¼hel!!!

KitzbÃ¼hel

January 2003 I came to Kitzbuhel for the first time. My feelings then were very different from what they are now. I was young, inexperienced, skinny and did not no what I was facing. I knew the legend of Kitzbuhel and I had seen the race in TV, but I had no idea what the course actually looked like up close. I was more of a slalom/giant slalom skier back then. But then I got a 6th place at the worldcup Super G in Val Gardena, and just like that I was  a speed skier as well.  I remember that day I was told by my coaches that I should race the Kitzbuhel downhill.  â€œThe downhill in Kitzbuhel is similar to the Super G, you should race it to be preparedâ€. I said ok, and for the next two weeks that was just about all I could think about. The unknown is a lot worse than knowing what youÂ´re facing. When we got to Kitbuhel I walked around town, up to the finish area and into some fields to try to get a look at the course. That didnâ€™t help much. I remember there were some forerunners testing the track, and they were crashing all over the place.  Not exactly what I hoped to see. But after the first inspection I felt better. I knew what I had to do and I could focus my energy on that. That being said I was incredibly nervous in the start gate. But thatÂ´s a part of the game, and I would lie if I said IÂ´m not nervous this week. But this time I am a lot better prepared, and IÂ´m ready to fight for the great Kitzbuhel victory. So wish me luck and lets hope for a weekend of fair and fun racing.

SURPRISE!!!
I had a great day yesterday! Thanks to some of the best people in the world.
Being born on the 26th of the December is not very convenient if youÂ´re a worldcup ski racer and you like celebrating your birthday with good friends. I usually spend my birthday alone in a car driving to Bormio. Kinda sad, but missing out on a worldcup race would be worse. So IÂ´m used to this being the way things are. And I could always have birthday parties when IÂ´m done racing. But this year IÂ´m turning 30 on the 26th. (I know, its kinda old and kinda scary!!) And it just seems very wrong to spend that day alone in a car.  I wanted to do something, but figured I would make up for it in the spring. Arranging a party at Christmas can be tough. EveryoneÂ´s busy with chrsitmas stuff, travelling etc. So when my brother said there was this new great restaurant right in the neighborhood, I didt think anything of it. Him, Julia and I walked over to grab something to eat, I thoughtâ€¦ Door opening and SURPRISE!!!!  Lots of my best friends and family. Couldnâ€™t have been better. Birthday party. A few days early, but still awesome. And the best thing about it is that you get to see all the people you wanna see, but there is just noe way you can when you only have three days in Norway. So thanks again to everybody that came. I had a great time!! And a special thanks to my brother Simen for putting together the whole thing, and to Julia for the great initiative! YouÂ´re great!!
